title: Standard Deviation and the Normal Distribution
description: Understand standard deviation as a measure of spread and explore the concept of normal distribution.
objectives: Calculate the standard deviation of a data set
Interpret standard deviation as a measure of spread
Understand the concept of normal distribution (bell curve)
Use the 68-95-99.7 rule for normally distributed data

sections.title: How Spread Out Is the Data?
sections.content:
Imagine two classes both have a mean test score of 70%. But in Class A, scores range from 65% to 75%, while in Class B they range from 30% to 100%. The means are the same, but the data is VERY different!

**Standard deviation** measures how spread out the data is from the mean. It's the most widely used measure of spread in statistics, used everywhere from quality control to medical research.

sections.title: Calculating Standard Deviation
sections.content:
The **standard deviation** ($\sigma$ for a population, $s$ for a sample) measures the average distance of data values from the mean.

**Formula:**
$$\sigma = \sqrt{\frac{\sum(x_i - \bar{x})^2}{n}}$$

**Steps:**
1. Calculate the mean ($\bar{x}$)
2. Find each deviation from the mean ($x_i - \bar{x}$)
3. Square each deviation
4. Find the mean of the squared deviations (this is the **variance**)
5. Take the square root

**Interpretation:**
- Small $\sigma$ → data is clustered close to the mean
- Large $\sigma$ → data is spread far from the mean
- $\sigma = 0$ → all values are identical

sections.title: The Normal Distribution
sections.content:
Many real-world data sets follow a **normal distribution** — a symmetric, bell-shaped curve. Examples include heights, weights, exam scores, and measurement errors.

**Properties of the normal distribution:**
- Symmetric about the mean
- Mean = median = mode (all at the centre)
- The curve is fully defined by its mean ($\mu$) and standard deviation ($\sigma$)

**The 68-95-99.7 Rule (Empirical Rule):**
- About **68%** of data falls within 1 standard deviation of the mean ($\mu \pm \sigma$)
- About **95%** falls within 2 standard deviations ($\mu \pm 2\sigma$)
- About **99.7%** falls within 3 standard deviations ($\mu \pm 3\sigma$)

sections.title: Using the 68-95-99.7 Rule
sections.content:
If a data set is normally distributed with mean $\mu = 170$ cm and $\sigma = 10$ cm:

- **68%** of values lie between $160$ cm and $180$ cm
- **95%** of values lie between $150$ cm and $190$ cm
- **99.7%** of values lie between $140$ cm and $200$ cm

This means a value above $190$ cm would be in the top 2.5% (very unusual), and a value above $200$ cm would be extremely rare (0.15%).

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
- **Standard deviation** ($\sigma$) measures how spread out data is from the mean
- Small $\sigma$ → consistent data; large $\sigma$ → variable data
- The **normal distribution** is a symmetric bell curve
- **68-95-99.7 rule:** 68% within $1\sigma$, 95% within $2\sigma$, 99.7% within $3\sigma$
- Values beyond $2\sigma$ from the mean are considered unusual

workedExamples.title: Interpreting Standard Deviation
workedExamples.problem: Two batsmen have batting averages of 45 runs. Batsman A has $\sigma = 5$ and Batsman B has $\sigma = 20$. Compare their consistency.
steps: Both have the same mean (45 runs)
Batsman A: $\sigma = 5$, so most scores are between 40 and 50 (very consistent)
Batsman B: $\sigma = 20$, so scores range widely from about 25 to 65 (inconsistent)
Batsman A is the more reliable scorer
workedExamples.answer: Batsman A is more consistent (smaller standard deviation).
workedExamples.explanation: A smaller standard deviation means less variation. Batsman A's scores cluster tightly around 45, while Batsman B's scores are highly variable.

workedExamples.title: Applying the 68-95-99.7 Rule
workedExamples.problem: The weights of apples from a farm are normally distributed with mean 200 g and standard deviation 15 g. What percentage of apples weigh between 170 g and 230 g?
steps: The range $\mu \pm 2\sigma$ contains about 95% of the data
workedExamples.explanation: 170 g and 230 g are each exactly 2 standard deviations from the mean. By the empirical rule, approximately 95% of apples fall in this range.

title: Conditional Probability and Expected Value
description: Explore conditional probability, stratified sampling, and the concept of expected value.
objectives: Understand stratified and other sampling methods
Use cumulative frequency to analyse data

sections.title: Probability With Extra Information
sections.content:
What's the probability that a randomly chosen person is taller than 180 cm? Now, what if I tell you the person is a professional basketball player? The extra information CHANGES the probability.

This is **conditional probability** — the probability of an event GIVEN that another event has occurred. It's fundamental to medical testing, weather forecasting, spam filters, and much more.

sections.title: Conditional Probability
sections.content:
The probability of event $A$ occurring, **given** that event $B$ has occurred:

$$P(A|B) = \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)}$$

The vertical bar $|$ means "given that".

**Example:** In a class of 30, 18 like maths, 15 like science, and 8 like both.

$P(\text{likes maths} | \text{likes science}) = \frac{P(\text{maths AND science})}{P(\text{science})} = \frac{8/30}{15/30} = \frac{8}{15}$

Given that a student likes science, there's an $\frac{8}{15}$ chance they also like maths.

**Important:** $P(A|B) \neq P(B|A)$ in general!

sections.title: Sampling Methods
sections.content:
How we select our sample affects the quality of our conclusions.

**Stratified sampling:** The population is divided into subgroups (strata), and we sample from each group proportionally.

Example: A school has 400 Year 7, 350 Year 8, and 250 Year 9 students. For a sample of 100:
- Year 7: $\frac{400}{1000} \times 100 = 40$ students
- Year 8: $\frac{350}{1000} \times 100 = 35$ students
- Year 9: $\frac{250}{1000} \times 100 = 25$ students

**Other methods:**
- **Simple random:** Every member has an equal chance of being selected
- **Systematic:** Select every $k$th member from a list
- **Convenience:** Select whoever is easiest to reach (least reliable)

sections.title: Expected Value
sections.content:
The **expected value** is the long-run average outcome of a random experiment.

$$E(X) = \sum x_i \times P(x_i)$$

Multiply each outcome by its probability, then add them all up.

**Example:** A game costs $\$2$ to play. You roll a die:
- Roll 6: win $\$10$ (profit $\$8$)
- Roll anything else: win nothing (loss $-\$2$)

$$E = 8 \times \frac{1}{6} + (-2) \times \frac{5}{6} = \frac{8}{6} - \frac{10}{6} = -\frac{2}{6} \approx -\$0.33$$

On average, you lose about 33 cents per game. The game favours the house!

sections.title: Conditional Probability from a Two-Way Table
sections.content: In a survey of 100 people: 40 males (25 drive to work, 15 catch public transport) and 60 females (30 drive, 30 catch PT). Find $P(\text{male} | \text{drives to work})$.

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
- **Conditional probability:** $P(A|B) = \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)}$ — probability of $A$ given $B$
- $P(A|B)$ is generally NOT equal to $P(B|A)$
- **Stratified sampling** ensures each subgroup is proportionally represented
- **Expected value** $= \sum x_i \times P(x_i)$ — the long-run average
- A negative expected value means a loss on average

workedExamples.title: Conditional Probability Calculation
workedExamples.problem: A bag has 5 red and 3 blue marbles. Two are drawn without replacement. Given that the first marble is red, what is the probability the second is also red?
steps: After drawing one red marble: 4 red and 3 blue remain (7 total)
workedExamples.explanation: Conditional probability adjusts for what we already know. Since one red has been removed, we work with the updated numbers: 4 red out of 7 total.

workedExamples.title: Expected Value of a Game
workedExamples.problem: A spinner has sections: Win $\$5$ (probability 0.2), Win $\$1$ (probability 0.3), Lose $\$2$ (probability 0.5). What is the expected value?
workedExamples.explanation: On average, you win 30 cents per spin. A positive expected value means the game favours the player.
